definition: to give orders/to spread news or rumors/to leak certain information intentionally
to put/to place/to release/to free/to let go/to let out/to set off (fireworks)
dialect/language/spoken words/speech/talk/words/conversation/what sb said/CL:種|种[zhong3],席[xi2],句[ju4],口[kou3],番[fan1]

sentences.english: The doubters, in fact, have already come forward.
sentences.chinese: 事实上，持怀疑观点的人已经出面放话了。

sentences.english: It's easy for DiCaprio's character to make this claim.
sentences.chinese: 迪卡普里奥的角色能这样放话到不困难。

sentences.english: He even promised to veto a stopgap measure.
sentences.chinese: 他甚至还放话要否决任何权益之计。

definition: to put about (a story, plan, threat etc)/to let it be known (esp. of threat or malicious story)/to threaten
to declare one's position/to say where one stands
see 誇海口|夸海口[kua1 hai3 kou3]
to signal the musicians (in Chinese opera, by prolonging a spoken word before attacking a song)/(coll.) to challenge
to have an acrimonious falling-out/to shed all pretense of cordiality/to tear into each other
to let go of sth held in one's mouth/(fig.) to relent/to yield
